description: Total number of possible matrices of order \(3 \times 3\) with each entry 2 or 0 is
solution:
Explanation:
A \(3 \times 3\) matrix has 9 elements and each element can be 2 or 0 i.e. each element can be chosen in 2 ways. Therefore, by using the fundamental principle of counting the total number of ways in which 9 elements can be chosen is \(2^{9}=512\). Hence, total number of matrices is 512 .

description: If \(\left[\begin{array}{cc}2 x+y & 4 x \\ 5 x-7 & 4 x\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}7 & 7 y-13 \\ y & x+6\end{array}\right]\), then the value of \(x+y\) is

\(

5 x-7 & 4 x

7 & 7 y-13 \\
y & x+6
\end{array}\right]
\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad 2 x+y=7,4 x=7 y-13,5 x-7=y, \)

\(4 x=x+6 \Rightarrow 
x=2, y=3 \Rightarrow

description: If \(A=\left[a_{i j}\right]\) is a square matrix of order 3 such that \(a_{i j}=i^{2}-j^{2}\), then \(A\) is

description: The number of elements below the diagonal of a square matrix of order \(n\) is
solution:
Explanation:
 There are \(n^{2}\) elements in a square matrix of order \(n\) out of which \(n\) elements are in the leading diagonal. So, the number of elements other than the diagonal elements is \(\left(n^{2}-n\right)\). Half of these elements are above the diagonal and half are below the diagonal. Hence, required number of elements is \(\frac{1}{2}\left(n^{2}-n\right)=\frac{1}{2} n(n-1)\).

description: If \(A\) and \(B\) are square matrices of the same order, then matrix \(\left(A B^{T}-B A^{T}\right)\) is a
solution:
Explanation:
We find that
\(
\left(A B^{T}-B A^{T}\right)^{T}=\left(A B^{T}\right)^{T}-\left(B A^{T}\right)^{T}\) 
\(=\left(B^{T}\right)^{T} A^{T}-\left(A^{T}\right)^{T} B^{T}=B A^{T}-A B^{T}\)
\(=-\left(A B^{T}-B A^{T}\right)
\)
\(\therefore \quad A B^{T}-B A^{T}\) is a skew-symmetric matrix.

description: If \(A\) is a square matrix such that \(A^{2}=I\), then \((A-I)^{3}+(A+I)^{3}-7 A\) is equal to
solution:
Explanation:
We find that the identity matrix \(I\) commutes with matrix \(A\) i.e. \(A I=A=I A\).
\(\therefore \quad(A-I)^{3}=A^{3}-3 A^{2}+3 A-I\) and \((A+I)^{3}\) 
\(=A^{3}+3 A^{2}+3 A+I\)
\(\Rightarrow \quad(A-I)^{3}+(A+I)^{3}-7 A=2 A^{3}+6 A-7 A\) \(=2\left(A^{2} A\right)+6 A-7 A\)
\(
=2(I A)+6 A-7 A=2 A+6 A-7 A=A
\)

description:
Let \(M\) be a \(3 \times 3\) matrix satisfying

\(M\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}-1 \\ 2 \\ 3\end{array}\right], M\left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -1 \\ 6\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ 1 \\ -1\end{array}\right]\) and, \(M=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}0 \\ 0 \\ 12\end{array}\right]\). 

Then the sum of the diagonal entries of \(M\), is
solution:
Explanation:
Let \(M=\left[\begin{array}{lll}a & b & c \\ x & y & z \\ l & m & n\end{array}\right]\). Then,
\(M\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}-1 \\ 2 \\ 3\end{array}\right] \Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}b \\ y \\ m\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}-1 \\ 2 \\ 3\end{array}\right]\)
\( \Rightarrow b=-1, y=2, m=3\)
\(\Rightarrow \quad M\left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ -1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}1 \\ 1 \\ -1\end{array}\right]\)
\( \Rightarrow a-b=1, x-y=1, l-m=-1 \)
\(\Rightarrow a=0, x=3, l=2\)
and, \(\quad M\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}0 \\ 0 \\ 12\end{array}\right]\)
\( \Rightarrow a+b+c=0, x+y+z=0, l+m+n=12 \) 
\(\Rightarrow c=1, z=-1, n=7\)
\(\therefore \quad\) Sum of diagonal elements of \(M=a+y+n\) \(=0+2+7=9\)

description: An \(n \times n\) matrix is formed using 0,1 and -1 as its elements. The number of such matrices which are skew-symmetric, is
solution:
Explanation:
All leading diagonal elements of a skew- symmetric are zero. So, to form a skew-symmketric matrix \(A=\left[a_{i j}\right]\) of order \(n \times n\), we need to know the elements \(a_{i j}\) for \(i<j ; i, j=1\), \(2, \ldots, n\). Each one of these \(\frac{n^{2}-n}{2}\) eiements can take three values 0,1 , and -1 . So, the number of skew-symmetric matrices is \(3^{\frac{n^{2}-n}{2}}=3^{\frac{n(n-1)}{2}}\).

description: If \(A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\alpha & 0 \\ 1 & 1\end{array}\right]\) and \(B=\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 0 \\ 5 & 1\end{array}\right]\), then the value of \(\alpha\) for which \(A^{2}=B\), is
solution:
Explanation:
We have,
\(
A^{2}=B \Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\alpha & 0 \\
1 & 1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\alpha & 0 \\
1 & 1
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
5 & 1
\end{array}\right]\)   
\(\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\alpha^{2} & 0 \\
\alpha+1 & 1
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
5 & 1
\end{array}\right]\)
\( \Rightarrow \alpha^{2}=1 \text { and } \alpha+1=5
\)
Clearly, these two equations are inconsistent. Hence, there is no value of \(\alpha\) satisfying \(A^{2}=B\).

If \(A B=B A\), then
[Pre-multiplying by \(A]\)
\(A(A B)=A(B A)\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad(A A) B=(A B) A \Rightarrow A^{2} B=(B A) A\)

\([\because A B=B A]\)

\(\Rightarrow \quad A^{2} B=B(A A) \Rightarrow A^{2} B=B A^{2}\)

Similarly, it can be shown that \(A^{n} B=B A^{n}\) (using the principle of mathematical induction).

=₹(46,000+53,000)-₹(31,000+36,000)=₹ 32,000
